review_blob: 2006 bottle. Pours a dark yet clear red with a small khaki head. Nose is oxidation and sweet caramel malts. Taste is the same with a touch of the rye spice. Loads of wet cardboard and faded hops but its still very tasty and drinkable. Held up well.

White capped 40 oz bottle with the paper bag. Mostly drank from the bottle but poured a bit out for my homies and to review. Hazyish light brown with a massive tan foam head. Nose is oxidation, bubble gum, sweet caramel, and corn. Taste is light caramel malts and faded hops. Has a certain character that I get from a lot of aged DFH beers. A sort of oxidized hop oil sweetness. Full mouth feel. Despite its age and the abv, its actually quite drinkable.

Pours a still dark and hazy brown, a few shades lighter then fresh cider. Nose is fresh cut apples. Seriously like cutting into a fresh crisp slightly acidic apple. Just a hint of maple in the nose. Taste is a generic apple flavor with some lingering maple sweetness. Sweet and somewhat earthy. Mild carb makes it pretty drinkable. Overall its pretty good and at a really nice price point.

Pours a dark red with a billowing khaki head. Nose is dank bud, pine, juicy melon, and sweet caramel malts. Taste is lots of pine, grapefruit, and caramel. Very bitter with a lingering "dankness" that never really reaches a weed level.  Very tasty red, wish it wasn?t in a 750 though.
beer_name: Founders Backstage Series #13: reDANKulous Imperial Red IPA

review_blob: 750 ml into tulip. Pours a deep clear red with a finger of tan foam. Nose is very barley wine or strong ale like with loads of dark fruits, caramel and booze. Some subtle smokiness and herbs as well as some brighter fruits on the end. The taste has the adjuncts shining and its departing from the nose. Caramel, cherries, lemon and brown sugar. Not much cocoa. The finish is tequila smoke and agave sweetness. The taste is really unique and excellent. Finishes with vanilla and toffee. Thick mouth feel, very boozy and warm. Really opens up as it warms. Really impressive beer.

Pours a jet black with mocha foam. Nose is fudge, cocoa, some cherry and cinnamon. Slightly peppery but not vegetal. Taste is cocoa and light cinnamon and vanilla then increasingly warming habaneros. The perfect heat, each sip is warming and lingers for a long time. A bit difficult to get through a whole bottle but this is an excellent pepper stout. Just behind Huna due to its tame cinnamon level.

22 oz bomber into a tulip. Pours a thick black with some lasting dark mocha foam. Nose is huge roasted malts with chocolate and a faint sweet orange extract. Taste opens up with roast and bright orange. Really has that Terrys chocolate orange thing going on. Rich and creamy, the lactose gives this an awesome mouth feel. Only improves and gets orangier as it warms up . Seriously impressed my this one, hell of a flavored stout!

Pours a nice hazy golden amber with plenty of white foam. Nose is wheat, light spice, and some faint peach juice. Taste is wheat, a little bitter spice, and the finish of subtle peaches. It really is faint but it  does come off as real and juicy. Would be nice if it were more up front but its very tasty and a refreshing summer beer. Not very tripel like but I really enjoy this.

Winter 2014 release. Pours a clear dark red with lasting khaki foam. Nose is rich butterscotch, maple, raisins, and toffee. Bourbon minus the heat, Irresistibly sweet and decadent. Taste is brown sugar and a rich toffee with slight burnt sugar/hop bitterness. Loads of maple and some booziness. This is an awesome barleywine! The barrel aging and blending is spot on!

Nose is vanilla, coffee, roasted malt, chocolate and some bright hops. Taste is bitter hops leading into chocolate and sweet vanilla. Cant tell if this actually contains vanilla but it sure does have that sweetness to it to help balance out the hops and roast. Thick and coating and a nice abv. Really solid beer.
beer_name: Lickinghole Creek Vanilla Virginia Black Bear

review_blob: Two 12 oz cans into a DLD chalice. Pours a clear amber with a finger of patchy white foam. Nose is loads of citrus and tropical fruits, chalk, and resin. Taste is juicy grapefruit, mango, and a touch of dankness. Definitely can detect the citra. Not overly bitter and finishes very clean. A very unique pale that really is super drinkable.

12 oz bottle into a tulip. Nose is rich chocolate, malted milk balls, light caramel malts and an almost earthy finish. Taste is lightly bitter chocolate with a smooth finish of cocoa and oats. Medium mouth feel with a lingering alcohol warmth and some molasses. Really awesome as an Irish style imperial stout.
beer_name: Shorts Moher Export Irish Imperial Stout

review_blob: 12 oz bottle into a tulip. Pours a golden amber with two fingers of white foam. Nose is grassy and grainy, bordering on skunky. Light citrus. Taste is grass, grains, faint hops and some lemon. Fairly boring and a little too grainy, but solid enough for the style.

2014 vintage into a tulip. Pours a dark brown/black with some thin khaki edging. Nose is toffee, caramel, vanilla, and barrel. Loads of dark fruits and some residual char and booze that almost borders on savory. Taste is dark fruits and butterscotch into smooth oak and vanilla with some marshmallow and alcohol warmth. Lingering dates and bourbon with a touch of oxidation. Very well integrated. This is an excellent BA BW, and a long time want which I randomly found in a wine cooler in VT. Steep price tag but well worth it,

Pours a clear golden with minimal head. Nose is caramel, vanilla and very mild coffee. Taste is sweet vanilla, caramel and toffee with a lingering light bitterness. Drinkable. Pretty unique, and like some people have mentioned it has a sugar cookie like favor.

22 oz bomber. April 2015 release. Pours a dark clear red with a finger of lazy off white foam. Nose is a lot of rye spice, floral hops, and some caramel. Taste is caramel with a nice rye kick. Floral and resinous hops in the background with a lingering bitterness. Not as dirty or harsh as other rye pales. One of the best ones Ive had to style, but its not overly exciting.
beer_name: Lawsons Finest Permagrin Rye Pale Ale

review_blob: 16 oz can into a pint. Pours your standard black with some tan lacing. Nose is a light roast with some faint chocolate and burnt coffee notes. A touch of vanilla. Very tame and subdued. Taste is smooth milk chocolate washed away by some lightly bitter roast. Sort of sweet. A bit thin and watery with a lingering generic coffee note. The problem with this beer is the deScription. Being from VT youre going in thinking this is a Hill Farmstead adjunct rich porter. It is not that at all. Its a light and easy drinking stout. I get none of the adjuncts. Definitely no maple or honey, and the coffee is so dialed back youd think it was just a plain old stout. Its still quite tasty and the fact that its in 16 oz cans and only 5.5% abv is really something. Maybe the perfect autumn camping beer?

From a 64 oz growler. Pours a clear amber with little lacing or head. Nose is grassy hops, a touch of spice, and some grainy cereal character. Taste is earthy and grassy hops finished by an almost caramel cereal like sweetness. A bit boozy, yet its highly drinkable. A little too easy to drink an entire growler of this. Nothing outstanding, but unique enough to make it memorable. Very nice beer.
beer_name: Kuhnhenn Double Rice India Pale Ale (DRIPA)

review_blob: 750 ml into a tulip. Nose is rich rich chocolate. Bordering bitter but still sweet. Light roast and vanilla. Taste is roast and a huge chocolate bomb. Rich, bitter, sweet with some vanilla and lactose. Less chocolate milk and more chocolate milk shake. Really thick and coating with the abv well hidden. Seriously, cant taste any alcohol. Delicious.
beer_name: Hardywood / Cigar City The Milkman Chocolate Milk Stout

review_blob: March 2015 batch into a wine glass. Pours a hazy amber yellow with long clinging white foam. Nose is clean grass, wheat, pepper and light tropical hops. Taste is wheat, light spices, lemon grass, some juicy hops and light light malt. A faint lingering bitter black pepper element. The hops arent exactly in your face and the brett is very mild and young making for a refreshing easy drinking tropical saison.

Pours a clear amber. Nose is surprisingly like the label says. Strong apricots and oranges along with some graininess and alcohol. Not very juicy, more like a dried apricot aroma. Taste is orange and dried apricots along with some light caramel malts and black tea. Damn myself for reading the label first! Clean and highly drinkable, its kind of in between a standard SN IPA and an ApriHop. Its really solid though.
beer_name: Sierra Nevada Harvest Single Hop IPA - Idaho 7

review_blob: 12 oz bottle into a tulip. 03/27/2015. Pours a pitch black with dark tan foam. Nose is strong fresh brewed espresso. It almost reaches that green pepper vegetal level but the sweetness keeps it in line. Chocolate, roast, vanilla, strong oak and booze round it out. Taste is sweet vanilla and strong french pressed coffee; kinda roasty and savory. Chocolate fudge and some light oak. Really delicious stuff. The first few sips are very boozy and hot but after a bit it sinks in and its smooth sailing from there. Thick and full mouth feel thats syrupy and sticky. This is a surprisingly big beer. One of the best coffee BA stouts Ive had and just a peg below some of the kings. A real surprise from Weyerbacher.

16 oz can into a tulip. Nose is juicy tropical citrus hops and clean crackery malts. Taste is mango, oranges, and lime zest with some of that unique crackery malt that is present in Eureka. Crisp and clean and highly crushable. This isnt vastly different from Lights Out, but its equally as delicious if not a slight bump better.

2014 batch, 375 ml. Pours a clear red/purple with light lacing. Nose is tart cranberries, grass, and... lemon hand soap? Chemical like, but not bad. Taste is grass and some lightly tart cranberry juice and cinnamon. Very one dimensional and frankly just boring. Theres nothing bad about this beer, its just very boring and standard vielle is much better.

2015 batch. 750 ml into a tulip. Pours a pale clear orange with minimal white lacing. Nose is big cinnamon and vanilla with a lactose/malty sweetness. Very odd and desert like. Taste is vanilla and spices followed by a sort of graininess and sweetness. I can swear I taste sweet rice, hell this tastes spot on like Kozy Shack rice pudding. I cant see this working for everyone. It really does taste like a horchata minus the body and texture, although its not exactly a thin beer. Its really weird, but kind of awesome. Im really enjoying this one.

2013-2014 750ml. Pours a dark dark red/brown with a finger of light khaki foam. Nose starts off very lambic like with lemons and funk with some dark fruit. Some chocolate and caramel but its very brett forward.  In some sniffs I get some burnt plastic. Taste is a nice balance of funky musk, grape juice then roast and chocolate malt. It comes off as a light beer despite being 7/8ths stout. Really complex and unique. Definitely mouth puckering. This is a weird beer, the lambic and stout really stand out and they somehow work here. Its still a goofy ass style, its been in my fridge for about three months before I said to myself that a soured stout sounds like a good idea. Its also expensive and I wish it saw the 375ml format instead. I dont know Tilquin...good job?

3 day old can into a tulip. Pours a hazy light amber yellow with a finger of white foam. Nose is tropical fruit, dank resin, and some crackery malts. Taste is hints of tropical fruit, oranges, and caramel all rounded out with some bitter pine. Its not a juicy mosaic bomb but its still present enough to make for a damn solid canned DIPA. Good job Grey Sail!

12 oz can into a pint. Thanks Max! Pours a dark red with a finger of tan foam. Nose is toffee, butterscotch, light citrus hops and some tobacco. Taste is smooth toffee and caramel with some roasted malts, coffee and lightly bitter hops. Creamy mouth feel. Over all a solid enough scotch ale.
beer_name: DC Brau The Stone of Arbroath

review_blob: Batch #1, Brewed in April 2014. Pours a dark brown/red with a finger of sticky dirty khaki foam. Nose is cherries, blackberries, and lactic acid. Lighter notes of vanilla, oak, and some brown sugar. Taste is cherries, brown sugar, and sour mouth puckering acidity. Finishes slightly sooth with some vanilla and leather. Similar to most American takes on an oud bruin. Dark fruits, acid, and oak with some slightly noticeable alcohol burn. Pretty solid though.

22 oz bomber into a tulip, right after trying the standard version. Color is the same, but now it is nice and hazy with a finger of off white foam versus a clear beer. Nose is...go figure, lemon juice and bitter resin with light caramel and wet malt. Taste is clean resin, malts, and an herbal bitter orange/lemon juice thing. Pretty unique, almost like an oz. of lemonade was seamlessly blended into the standard beer. Still nice and balanced, but that little lemon kiss is pretty damn nice. Cool hop variety, cool beer.
beer_name: Clown Shoes Lemon Drop Space Cake

review_blob: 22 oz bomber into a tulip. Pours a standard clear dark amber with a finger or two of white foam. Nose is standard east coast style; caramel malts with bitter grapefruit and some piney resin. Just a hint of tropical juice. Taste is grapefruit and caramel ending with some orange. Big balance of hops and malt, really just right in the middle. Overall its a solid enough DIPA but it just hints at the juiciness of mosaic.

09/12/2014. Pours a dark brown almost black with a finger of lazy tan foam. Nose is smokey wood without being savory, vanilla, molasses, and some dark fruits. Smells massive and bourbon heavy. Taste is brown sugar, prunes, vanilla, oak and toffee. Lingering wood and molasses. Certainly boozy but not in a detracting way. Thick and syrupy, but not at the Bruery level. Pretty massive with tons of flavor, hell of a shelf beer.

02/26/2010 batch. Aged in probably less then stellar conditions, recently snagged off of a beer stores shelf. Pours a clear golden amber with little edging. Nose is cardboard, metal, apricots, wheat, and bubble gum. Taste is similar, fading stone fruits and yeast esters with some oxidized cardboard and faded bitterness. Its well over the hill, and far from great, but it remains drinkable at five years old.

2015 version, 750 ml into a tulip. Pours a dark red with a finger of pink tinged khaki foam. Nose is straight raspberry jam with a touch of yeast esters. Fresh, vibrant and intense raspberry pulp. Taste is the same with a slight spice and wheat/yeast kick to it. Alcohol is hidden really well. Has an almost spritz like finish despite being so rich.  Just a crazy delicious wall of fruit. Glad to have this one back.
UPDATED: FEB 28, 2015
beer_name: Stillwater / Against The Grain Rio De Sauvin

review_blob: 375 ml into a tumbler. Pours a clear golden amber with rising carb and a finger of white foam. Very gueuze looking. Nose is sour apples, wet grain, and a slightly skunked/musky off putting note. Taste is better. Pretty unique mix of sour apples, caramel malts, and a slightly rotting funk thing. Not bad per se, just different. Havent had a sour similar to this one. Like a tame malty gueuze.

16 oz can into a tulip. Pours a hazy orange with a finger of dense white foam. Nose is tropical citrus, oranges and mango juice with some wet grain. Taste is juicy orange and mango with a light bitterness and a nice crisp crackery finish. Light enough to stand out from their IPAs but still full of flavor. Just a crazy delicious pale and so perfect in cans.

750 ml into a tulip. Pours a very dark red, almost black with a finger of khaki foam. Nose is dark fruits, lactic acid, sour cherries, and vanilla heavy oak. Taste is sour cherries, warm oak, and a nice lactic twang. Faint smoke on the finish. Very well balanced and has that American oude bruin thing going on. Really solid wild.

Can into a pint. Just a few days old. Pours a super hazy amber orange. Nose is peaches and mangos with just a hint of dank herbalness. Taste is peach juice and biscuits. Barely bitter and super juicy. A really impressive and highly drinkable APA.

Nose is roast, fudgey chocolate, light coffee grinds and vanilla. Taste is a nice balance of sweet rich chocolate and lightly bitter roast. Touch of caramel and coffee. Creamy and full. Just a really solid Russian imperial leaning on the sweet side.

750 ml bottle into a tulip. Pours a clear golden yellow with some billowing foam. Nose is standard saison with a little bit of wine notes creeping out as it warms. Grass, spices, wheat, brett and a touch of green grape juice on the end. Taste is again, that standard Americanized saison profile of wheat, black pepper and some grassy herbalness with a unique finish of sweet and juicy white wine, light bitterness, and the beginnings of some funky sour bugs. Really tasty stuff. Creamy mouth feel with nice carb. Not the most complex or interesting of wine barrel aged saison, but a really delicious and well made one.

Bottled March 2014. Pours a dark brown/red with fizzing carb. Nose is cherries, wheat, musky funk and vanilla. Taste is initially mouth puckering cherries and a sweaty musky funk. Wheat heavy with some oak and caramel. Less berliner and more oud bruin. Pretty unique stuff.
beer_name: Schell Noble Star  #3 - North Country Brnette

review_blob: 500 ml into a tulip. Pours a dark brown which is nearly black but lets some light through. Zero head. Nose is roast, vanilla, chocolate and light dark fruit. Not very barrel forward, but certainly vanilla forward, Taste is chocolate and sweet vanilla with a touch of alcohol and bitter roast. Alcohol is there but not at all an issue. I wouldnt believe it was 15% at all. However it is thin and kind of underwhelming. Kind of an odd ball beer. Id rather have standard BA Framinghammer but this is still really tasty.

750 ml into a tulip, Thanks Kevin! Pours a pitch black with a dark mocha head. Nose is roasted malts and chocolate. Left to breath and warm up you get some of those rum notes. Spices, oak, molasses, and loads of vanilla. Taste is bitter roast, a touch of smoke, chocolate fudge and light spices and vanilla. Creamy and thick mouth feel for being only 10% abv. Really delicious stuff here, the nose edges out the taste a bit though. Not overly rum forward but enough to make it stand out.

750 ml into a tulip. Nose is a great blend of fresh coffee and roasted chocolate malts. Just a hint of that high end pepperyness ala BCBCS. Taste is roast, caramel sweetness, milk chocolate, then bitter coffee beans. Ends with a slight savory note. Smooth and coating. Very tasty and highly drinkable

December 2014 release, 22 oz bomber into a tulip. Pours a pitch black with minimal mocha lacing that fades away to nothing. Nose is roast and bitter bakers chocolate. Faint notes of dark fruits, vanilla and coffee but its fairly one dimensional. Taste is creamy milk chocolate, roasted malts with some caramel and coffee, and sharp cocoa nibs. Very well balanced and tasty. Rich and full mouth feel with an almost dry bitter finish. A pretty straight forward porter, but the flavors are really spot on. Really solid beer.

750 ml into a tulip. Pours a pitch black with a thin dark mocha edging. Nose is dark chocolate, light anise, vanilla and roasted coffee.Taste is oak, vanilla, and loads of dark chocolate and light roasted coffee beans. Warming booze but its hidden quite well. Maple isnt very apparent but this is a damn good BA stout. Kind of like a milder BA Narwhal with some light coffee notes.
beer_name: Sierra Nevada Barrel Aged Maple Stout

review_blob: 22 oz bomber into a tulip. Thanks Kevin! Pours a pitch black with a finger of khaki foam. Thick lacing. Nose indicates its got a bit of age on it. Fudge brownies, bourbony oak and vanilla, and a touch of ripe dark fruits on the end, Taste is huge fudgy chocolate, creamy and smooth with just a touch of bitterness. Light oak and vanilla. Finishes dry with a lingering but pleasant woodiness. A bit thin on the mouth feel. The nose is pretty amazing on this and the taste is really great minus an oak bitterness. Really impressive beer.

750ml into a tulip. Thanks Kevin! Pours a pitch black with a finger of lasting mocha foam. Nose is chocolate, coffee, vanilla, oak, and heavy rye whiskey. Smells incredible. Ends with a bit of a spiced kick. Taste is smooth chocolate, vanilla, and oak. Lighter notes of brown sugar and caramel. Thick and coating mouth feel with a lingering burnt vanilla and rye spice. Its sad to see the hoppy original disappear in bottles, but these rye barrels turned this into an amazing BA stout. Just incredible this year.
750 ml into a tulip. Nose is pine and citrus. Bitter and juicy. Taste is much better with the pine and citrus mingling with some bubble gum and tropical fruit in the finish, Really tasty DIPA.
beer_name: Steel Toe Sticker Fight Double IPA
